file_metadata.title: Bioelectric signalling via potassium channels: a mechanism for craniofacial dysmorphogenesis in KCNJ2‐associated Andersen–Tawil Syndrome
file_metadata.abstract:
<jats:sec><jats:title>Key points</jats:title><jats:p><jats:list list-type="bullet">
<jats:list-item><jats:p><jats:italic>Xenopus laevis</jats:italic> craniofacial development is a good system for the study of Andersen–Tawil Syndrome (ATS)‐associated craniofacial anomalies (CFAs) because (1) <jats:italic>Kcnj2</jats:italic> is expressed in the nascent face; (2) molecular‐genetic and biophysical techniques are available for the study of ion‐dependent signalling during craniofacial morphogenesis; (3) as in humans, expression of variant <jats:italic>Kcnj2</jats:italic> forms in embryos causes a muscle phenotype; and (4) variant forms of <jats:italic>Kcnj2</jats:italic> found in human patients, when injected into frog embryos, cause CFAs in the same cell lineages.</jats:p></jats:list-item>
<jats:list-item><jats:p>Forced expression of WT or variant <jats:italic>Kcnj2</jats:italic> changes the normal pattern of <jats:italic>V</jats:italic><jats:sub>mem</jats:sub> (resting potential) regionalization found in the ectoderm of neurulating embryos, and changes the normal pattern of expression of ten different genetic regulators of craniofacial development, including markers of cranial neural crest and of placodes.</jats:p></jats:list-item>
<jats:list-item><jats:p>Expression of other potassium channels and two different light‐activated channels, all of which have an effect on <jats:italic>V</jats:italic><jats:sub>mem</jats:sub>, causes CFAs like those induced by injection of <jats:italic>Kcnj</jats:italic>2 variants. In contrast, expression of <jats:italic>Slc9A</jats:italic> (NHE3), an electroneutral ion channel, and of <jats:italic>GlyR</jats:italic>, an inactive Cl<jats:sup>−</jats:sup> channel, do not cause CFAs, demonstrating that correct craniofacial development depends on a pattern of bioelectric states, not on ion‐ or channel‐specific signalling.</jats:p></jats:list-item>
<jats:list-item><jats:p>Using optogenetics to control both the location and the timing of ion flux in developing embryos, we show that affecting <jats:italic>V</jats:italic><jats:sub>mem</jats:sub> of the ectoderm and no other cell layers is sufficient to cause CFAs, but only during early neurula stages. Changes in <jats:italic>V</jats:italic><jats:sub>mem</jats:sub> induced late in neurulation do not affect craniofacial development.</jats:p></jats:list-item>
<jats:list-item><jats:p>We interpret these data as strong evidence, consistent with our hypothesis, that ATS‐associated CFAs are caused by the effect of variant <jats:italic>Kcnj2</jats:italic> on the <jats:italic>V</jats:italic><jats:sub>mem</jats:sub> of ectodermal cells of the developing face. We predict that the critical time is early during neurulation, and the critical cells are the ectodermal cranial neural crest and placode lineages. This points to the potential utility of extant, ion flux‐modifying drugs as treatments to prevent CFAs associated with channelopathies such as ATS.</jats:p></jats:list-item>
</jats:list></jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Variants in potassium channel <jats:italic>KCNJ2</jats:italic> cause Andersen–Tawil Syndrome (ATS); the induced craniofacial anomalies (CFAs) are entirely unexplained. We show that <jats:italic>KCNJ2</jats:italic> is expressed in <jats:italic>Xenopus</jats:italic> and mouse during the earliest stages of craniofacial development. Misexpression in <jats:italic>Xenopus</jats:italic> of <jats:italic>KCNJ2</jats:italic> carrying ATS‐associated mutations causes CFAs in the same structures affected in humans, changes the normal pattern of membrane voltage potential regionalization in the developing face and disrupts expression of important craniofacial patterning genes, revealing the endogenous control of craniofacial patterning by bioelectric cell states. By altering cells’ resting potentials using other ion translocators, we show that a change in ectodermal voltage, not tied to a specific protein or ion, is sufficient to cause CFAs. By adapting optogenetics for use in non‐neural cells in embryos, we show that developmentally patterned K<jats:sup>+</jats:sup> flux is required for correct regionalization of the resting potentials and for establishment of endogenous early gene expression domains in the anterior ectoderm, and that variants in <jats:italic>KCNJ2</jats:italic> disrupt this regionalization, leading to the CFAs seen in ATS patients.</jats:p></jats:sec>

chunks.text: Mutations in KCNJ2, the gene encoding the Kir2.1 inwardly rectifying potassium channel, are implicated in Andersen-Tawil Syndrome (ATS), a disorder characterized by cardiac arrhythmias, periodic paralysis, and craniofacial anomalies (CFAs).  CFAs in ATS manifest as a variety of facial features including broad forehead and nose, wide-set eyes, low-set ears, small lower jaw, and digit abnormalities.  While the link between KCNJ2 mutations and cardiac/paralysis symptoms is understood, the cause of CFAs remained unknown.  Alcohol binding to Kir2.1 has also been proposed as a mechanism for CFAs in fetal alcohol syndrome.  This study investigates the role of Kir2.1 and bioelectric signaling in craniofacial development using Xenopus laevis as a model organism.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study investigates the role of KCNJ2 mutations and bioelectric signaling in the craniofacial anomalies observed in Andersen-Tawil Syndrome.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The study hypothesizes that Kir2.1's role in establishing correct membrane voltage (Vmem) patterns in the developing face is crucial for normal craniofacial development.  Previous research has demonstrated the importance of Vmem gradients in organ positioning during embryogenesis.  Vmem influences cellular processes like proliferation, migration, and orientation, all of which are essential for facial feature development.  This study aims to test the hypothesis that disrupted Vmem patterns due to Kir2.1 mutations cause the CFAs observed in ATS, using Xenopus laevis as a model system due to its established use in developmental biology and craniofacial studies.
chunks.chunk_summary: The study hypothesizes that Kir2.1-regulated Vmem patterns are essential for normal craniofacial development and that disruptions in these patterns cause CFAs in ATS.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Kir2.1 is a potassium channel protein that forms homotetramers to facilitate potassium efflux, crucial for repolarizing excitable cell membranes after an action potential.  Its activity is regulated by various factors, including spermine, spermidine, Mg2+, phosphorylation, and PIP2 binding.  While primarily known for its role in cardiac myocyte membrane voltage control, Kir2.1 also contributes to the resting potential of undifferentiated embryonic cells, influencing cellular functions beyond action potential propagation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Kir2.1 is a potassium channel protein that regulates membrane voltage in various cell types, including embryonic cells.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Xenopus laevis embryos were obtained and staged according to standard protocols. Mouse embryos were also used for comparative analysis.  mRNA encoding various KCNJ2 variants, wildtype KCNJ2, and other channel proteins were injected into Xenopus embryos.  Embryos were raised to stage 45 and scored for CFAs.  In situ hybridization (ISH) was performed to analyze KCNJ2 expression patterns in both Xenopus and mouse embryos.
chunks.chunk_summary: Xenopus and mouse embryos were used to study the effects of KCNJ2 variants and wildtype KCNJ2 on craniofacial development using mRNA injection and in situ hybridization.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Membrane voltage was measured using fluorescent dyes DiBAC4(3), CC2-DMPE, and Oxonol VI.  Images were processed to quantify Vmem differences between variant-expressing and non-expressing cells.  An optogenetics system was developed using a Nikon AZ100 stereomicroscope and a Spectra 4 light engine to control light stimulation.  A microfluidic chip was designed to hold Xenopus embryos during light treatments and imaging.
chunks.chunk_summary: Membrane voltage was measured using fluorescent dyes, and an optogenetics system with a microfluidic chip was used for controlled light stimulation of embryos.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Statistical analysis was performed using chi-squared tests to compare the proportion of CFAs in treated embryos with controls.  Effect size was predetermined.  Box and whisker plots were used to visualize the data.
chunks.chunk_summary: Chi-squared tests were used to compare CFA proportions between treated and control embryos, with a predetermined effect size and data visualization using box plots.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: KCNJ2 expression was analyzed in Xenopus and mouse embryos. In Xenopus, KCNJ2 was expressed in dorsoanterior regions at the neural plate stage, then in the anterior neural folds and somites at later stages. In mice, KCNJ2 was expressed in the midline and lateral to neural folds at E8.5, then in somites, frontonasal process, mandible, palatal shelves, and developing limbs at later stages.  These expression patterns suggest a role for KCNJ2 in craniofacial development in both species.
chunks.chunk_summary: KCNJ2 is expressed in developing craniofacial structures in both Xenopus and mouse embryos, suggesting a role in craniofacial patterning.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Injection of KCNJ2 variants and wildtype KCNJ2 mRNA into Xenopus embryos resulted in a significant increase in CFAs, primarily affecting the eyes, jaws, and branchial arches.  Control injections did not produce a significant increase in CFAs.  Other potassium channel variants (Kir6.2, KvLQT) and optogenetic reagents also induced CFAs.  These results indicate that KCNJ2 activity and Vmem manipulation influence craniofacial development.
chunks.chunk_summary: KCNJ2 variants, wildtype KCNJ2, and other channel manipulations caused a significant increase in craniofacial anomalies in Xenopus embryos.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: KCNJ2 variant expression also caused muscle abnormalities in Xenopus tails, including disrupted fibronectin organization.  This finding further supports the use of Xenopus as a model for ATS and provides insights into the role of KCNJ2 in muscle development.
chunks.chunk_summary: KCNJ2 variants caused muscle abnormalities in Xenopus tails, further validating the model's relevance to ATS.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The D71V variant altered the normal Vmem pattern in Xenopus embryos, depolarizing expressing cells and hyperpolarizing adjacent cells.  Other variants also produced predicted Vmem changes.  These results suggest that KCNJ2 variants disrupt Vmem regionalization during development, potentially through cell-autonomous and non-cell-autonomous mechanisms.
chunks.chunk_summary: KCNJ2 variants, particularly D71V, disrupted normal Vmem patterns in Xenopus embryos, affecting both expressing cells and their neighbors.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: KCNJ2 variants disrupted the expression patterns of genes involved in neural crest and placode development, including Fgf8, Six1, Pax2, Sox3, Fz3, Slug, Sox10, Otx2, FoxE4, and Pax6.  These findings suggest that Vmem changes caused by KCNJ2 variants affect downstream gene expression, potentially contributing to CFAs.
chunks.chunk_summary: KCNJ2 variants disrupted the expression of genes crucial for craniofacial development, linking Vmem changes to downstream genetic pathways.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Optogenetic manipulation of Vmem using Channelrhodopsin2-D156A (ChR2-D156A) in Xenopus embryos resulted in increased CFAs, indicating that ectodermal Vmem changes are sufficient to cause craniofacial abnormalities.  Experiments with Archaerhodopsin (Arch) showed that Vmem manipulation during early neurulation is critical for craniofacial development.
chunks.chunk_summary: Optogenetic manipulation confirmed that ectodermal Vmem changes during early neurulation are sufficient to cause craniofacial anomalies.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Variants of other potassium channels (Kir6.2, KvLQT) also induced CFAs, suggesting that Vmem control, rather than a specific Kir2.1 function, is crucial for craniofacial patterning.  These results support the hypothesis that Vmem is a key regulator of craniofacial development.
chunks.chunk_summary: Manipulation of Vmem through other potassium channels also caused CFAs, highlighting the importance of Vmem control in craniofacial development.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: This study provides evidence for a mechanism linking KCNJ2 variants to CFAs in ATS.  Kir2.1 activity contributes to the Vmem prepattern in the developing face, which regulates gene expression crucial for neural crest and placode development.  Vmem, rather than a specific Kir2.1 function, is the critical parameter for craniofacial morphogenesis.  Ectodermal Vmem changes during early neurulation are sufficient to cause CFAs.
chunks.chunk_summary: The study proposes a mechanism where KCNJ2-dependent Vmem patterns regulate craniofacial development, and disruptions in these patterns lead to CFAs in ATS.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: KCNJ2 variants disrupt the bioelectric face pattern, affecting Vmem in both expressing and adjacent cells.  This non-cell-autonomous signaling may involve voltage-gated channels, ion transporters, or gap junctions.  KCNJ2 variants also disrupt the expression of genes involved in face patterning.  These findings suggest that Vmem regionalization in the ectoderm is critical for normal craniofacial development.
chunks.chunk_summary: KCNJ2 variants disrupt bioelectric signaling, affecting Vmem and gene expression in the developing face, leading to craniofacial anomalies.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Vmem control, rather than a specific Kir2.1 function, is the critical parameter for face morphogenesis.  Manipulating Vmem through H+ flux also causes CFAs and gene expression disruptions.  This suggests that the endogenous Vmem pattern is crucial for craniofacial development and can be disrupted by various ion channel defects.
chunks.chunk_summary: Vmem control is essential for craniofacial morphogenesis, and disruptions in Vmem patterns, regardless of the specific ion channel involved, can lead to developmental defects.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Both depolarizing and hyperpolarizing channel constructs caused similar CFAs, suggesting that specific Vmem ranges are required for proper downstream effector function.  Disrupting these Vmem ranges interferes with morphogenesis.  KCNJ2 variants also caused muscle defects in Xenopus, further supporting the model's relevance to ATS.
chunks.chunk_summary: Specific Vmem ranges are necessary for normal craniofacial development, and deviations in either direction can disrupt downstream processes and lead to similar anomalies.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Vmem changes affect the expression of genes critical for facial patterning, with variations in expression patterns observed.  The variability in gene expression changes may contribute to the variable CFAs seen in ATS patients.  Further research is needed to understand the link between Vmem, gene expression, and morphological variation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Vmem changes influence the expression of genes involved in facial patterning, and the variability in these changes may contribute to the phenotypic variability observed in ATS.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: This study demonstrates the first use of optogenetics to manipulate bioelectric states in developing embryos.  Optogenetic manipulation of Vmem provides greater temporal and spatial resolution than previous methods.  This technique has potential applications in understanding and manipulating bioelectrical signals in various developmental contexts.
chunks.chunk_summary: Optogenetics is a valuable tool for manipulating bioelectric states in developing embryos, offering improved spatial and temporal control for studying developmental processes.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Other channelopathies, caused by variants in other ion channels, also induce patterning defects.  This Xenopus model of ATS provides a platform for studying the role of ion channels in craniofacial development and exploring potential therapeutic interventions.
chunks.chunk_summary: Other channelopathies also cause developmental defects, and this Xenopus model of ATS provides a useful system for studying the role of ion channels in craniofacial development.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The CFAs associated with ATS are caused by KCNJ2 malfunction disrupting Vmem patterns in the anterior ectoderm during early craniofacial development.  These Vmem anomalies lead to misexpression of craniofacial genes, resulting in mispatterning of neural crest and placode lineages and ultimately contributing to CFAs.  This study suggests potential therapeutic strategies using ion channel-modulating drugs to address birth defects.
chunks.chunk_summary: KCNJ2 malfunction disrupts Vmem patterns, leading to gene misexpression and craniofacial anomalies, suggesting potential therapeutic strategies using ion channel-modulating drugs.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: This study provides a mechanistic explanation for craniofacial anomalies in ATS, linking KCNJ2 mutations to disrupted bioelectric signaling and downstream gene misexpression.  This research highlights the importance of bioelectricity in development and suggests potential therapeutic approaches using ion channel-modifying drugs.
chunks.chunk_summary: The study's findings on the role of bioelectricity in craniofacial development have implications for understanding and potentially treating craniofacial anomalies in ATS and other channelopathies.
chunks.authors: ["Dany Spencer Adams", "Sebastien G.M. Uzel", "Jin Akagi", "Donald Wlodkowicz", "Viktoria Andreeva", "Pamela Crotty Yelick", "Adrian Devitt-Lee", "Jean-Francois Pare", "Michael Levin"]
